main_text:
Selves: Human and Divine
4. Selves: Human and Divine

The eighth of the nine Vaiśeṣika types of substance is
‘self’ (ātman), defined as the substratum of
mental states such as believing, knowing, etc. (The ninth is
‘mind’ (manas), a distinct element in the
ontology of the mental.) Selves are divided into two types—human
(jīva) and divine (paramātman;
īśvara). The Manual of Reason supplies
arguments (all traceable back to earlier authors) for the existence of
both types of self.
entry_title: Analytic Philosophy in Early Modern India
